commentBody:
"(I didn’t pay for it. Seeking publicity for the program and also possibly for the Nets, who are having a bad season and suffering from low attendance, Brooklyn Sports and Entertainment offered The New York Times a look at it.)"

I'm baffled that this article, which seems to violate the NYT's ethical guidelines against accepting freebies, got the green light. Yes, Sarah Lyall is a terrific writer, and she somewhat bites the hand that feeds her this $6,189 gift package.

But it's still an advertisement of sorts for the Brooklyn Nets, the Barclays Center and their VIP packages. After all, the Times has parted ways with freelancers who accepted travel junkets *from other publications."
http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/03/opinion/03pubed.html

And the Times Handbook (p. 10) warns against accepting hospitality from sources.
http://www.nytco.com/wp-content/uploads/NYT_Ethical_Journalism_0904-1.pdf
--"Whenever practical, however, the reporter should suggest dining where The Times can pay."
--"Staff members may not accept free or discounted transportation and lodging except where special circumstances give us little or no choice."

But this was no "military or scientific expedition," the examples given. Yes, press passes to cultural and sporting events are OK, but this was a VIP package.

I'd be interested to learn what the Public Editor thinks.

Norman Oder
Atlantic Yards/Pacific Park Report
Brooklyn, NY
